page.title: 14A Walk in Lavenham Part 1
page.content: Opposite the boys entrance of the Primary School is one of the oldest houses in Lavenham,built by William Jacob,a wool trader.Notice the wooden door-wide enough to allow the bales of wool to enter the house.Approaching Market Hill,on the right, is another 14th Century building,now the head- quarters of the Suffolk Preservation Society.The little windows at the ends of the roof were smoke holes for smoke to escape in the days when there were no chimneys and the fire was in the middle of the floor.The larger windows downstairs were important to allow maximum light for the spinners and weavers to work by.The Market Cross was built by William Jacob.It was here that the Lord of the Manor met his men and explained their duties.The Toll Cottage nearby was where rent was paid for having a stall on the Market.
